FIGURE 5.7 Behaviour of magnetic field lines near a

(a) diamagnetic,
(b) paramagnetic substance.

The simplest explanation for diamagnetism is as follows.

Electrons in an atom orbiting around nucleus possess orbital angular momentum.

These orbiting electrons are equivalent to current-carrying loop and thus possess orbital magnetic moment.
summary: Diamagnetism is defined as the behaviour of an atom or a molecule with no net magnetic moment in the presence of an external magnetic field. In diamagnetism, the alignment of magnetic moments of individual atoms is negatiively affected, resulting in a slight weakening of the net magnetic moment.
hypothetical_questions: What is the difference between paramagnetism and diamagnetism?
